question: Question_10
statement:
Suppose that

\[f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}\] is a bounded function and that
$\{a_n\}$ is a sequence that converges to 0. Prove that

\[\lim_{n \to \infty} f(n)a_n = 0\]
sols:
Since $f$ is bounded there exists a constant \emph{M} such that

\[|f(n)|<M \quad\text{for all } n\in \mathbb{N}\]

We will show that $\{f(n)a_n\}$ converges to zero. Let $\epsilon>0$.
Since $\{a_n\}$ converges to zero there exists a positive integer
\emph{N}\textsubscript{ε} such that

\[|a_n|<\frac{\epsilon}{M} \quad\text{for all } n>N_\epsilon\] Hence

\[|f(n)a_n|=|f(n)||a_n|<M\frac{\epsilon}{M}=\epsilon \quad\text{for all } n>N_\epsilon\]
This shows that $\{f(n)a_n\}$ converges to zero.
hints:
Show that if $\{a_n\}$ is a sequence converging to zero and \emph{M} is
a constant then the sequence $\{Ma_n\}$ also converges to zero.
